content: The "American Timber Supply and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows for an investment incentive for domestic timber production under section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "American Timber Supply and Manufacturing Incentives Act" under section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers with qualified timber gain to deduct a percentage of such gain from gross income. Qualified timber gain is the lesser of net capital gain for the year or net capital gain from qualified timber. Qualified timber is timber where processing will mostly occur within the United States. The "American Timber Supply and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows taxpayers to deduct a qualified percentage of timber gain from gross income, with qualified timber being timber processed mostly within the United States. The deduction excludes gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets for estates and trusts. Coordination with existing limitations on capital gains rates is also addressed. The "American Timber Supply and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows taxpayers to deduct a qualified percentage of timber gain from gross income, with qualified timber being timber processed mostly within the United States. The Act also amends various sections of the tax code to exclude qualified timber gain from the maximum capital gains rate and alternative tax for corporations. Additionally, a new deduction is allowed for domestic timber production in computing adjusted gross income. Conforming Amendment: The tax code is amended to include a new item in the table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section provide an investment incentive for domestic timber production, effective for sales or exchanges after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, passive loss limitations are applied to timber activities. The amendments provide an investment incentive for domestic timber production, with passive loss limitations applied to timber activities. Material participation in timber activities is defined as substantial involvement compared to other individuals in the activity. The amendments provide an investment incentive for domestic timber production, with passive loss limitations applied to timber activities. Material participation in timber activities is defined as substantial involvement compared to other individuals in the activity. Taxpayers must participate in the activity on a regular, continuous, and substantial basis, with oversight supervision and control by the taxpayer. The determination of material participation in timber activities for partners and S corporation shareholders is based on their substantial involvement compared to others in the activity, with oversight, supervision, and control by the taxpayer. The amendment applies to partners and shareholders in a partnership or S corporation participating in timber activities, effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4.
